title: Earl McGrath Was a Character. His Closet Was Filled With Rare Recordings.
abstract: When the art and music world figure died in 2016, he left behind a trove of reels from his years scouting for his own label and the one he ran for the Rolling Stones.
des_facet: Earls Closet: The Lost Archive of Earl McGrath, 1970-1980 (Album)

multimedia.caption: Earl McGrath transformed himself from a Midwestern dishwasher to a beloved member of Hollywood and New York artistic circles.
Earl McGrath transformed himself from a Midwestern dishwasher to a beloved member of Hollywood and New York artistic circles.
Earl McGrath transformed himself from a Midwestern dishwasher to a beloved member of Hollywood and New York artistic circles.

title: Does Public Art Have an Afterlife?
abstract: Public artworks have the power to uplift a city. Sometimes they end up in a museum, but other times in a dumpster.

multimedia.caption: Pamela Council at a storage facility in Brooklyn, with the disassembled pieces from “A Fountain for Survivors,” a public artwork shown in Times Square last year. Council has raised money to buy time to find it a permanent home.
multimedia.copyright: Vincent Tullo for The New York Times

title: Review: Danai Gurira Makes a Sleek Supervillain of Richard III
abstract: At Shakespeare in the Park, athletic stamina and action-hero charisma muddy the meaning of a play about disability.

multimedia.caption: Danai Gurira as Richard and Daniel J. Watts as a henchman in “Richard III.”
Danai Gurira as Richard and Daniel J. Watts as a henchman in “Richard III.”

title: With Sign Language and Sound, an Artist Upends Audience Perceptions
abstract: Christine Sun Kim’s poetic and political art pushes viewers to consider the limits, and misunderstandings, that come with communication in any language, whether spoken or signed.

multimedia.caption: The artist Christine Sun Kim, whose work challenges viewers to reconsider how they hear and perceive the world.

title: Lea Michele to Star in ‘Funny Girl’ After Beanie Feldstein’s Departure
abstract: The former “Glee” star will share the stage with Tovah Feldshuh, who will replace Jane Lynch as Fanny Brice’s mother, starting Sept. 6.

multimedia.caption: Lea Michele at the Tony Awards last month. She performed with members of the original cast of “Spring Awakening.”

title: ‘Into the Woods’ Review: Do You Believe in Magic?
abstract: The Encores! revival of this fairy-tale musical, with songs by Stephen Sondheim, arrives on Broadway with its humor, wonder and humanity intact.

multimedia.caption: Gavin Creel, left, as the Wolf and Julia Lester as Little Red Riding Hood in the musical “Into the Woods” at the St. James Theater.

title: ‘Paradise Square’ Will Close on Broadway After Winning One Tony
abstract: The new musical was an unsuccessful comeback attempt by the storied producer Garth H. Drabinsky.

multimedia.caption: Joaquina Kalukango as Nelly O’Brien in “Paradise Square” at the Ethel Barrymore Theater.

title: A Self-Taught Artist Takes His Roadside Acropolis North
abstract: Outside the art establishment for decades, Charles Smith has sculpted his Black heroes in Aurora, Ill., and now in Hammond, La. At 81, he’s getting his first show in New York.

multimedia.caption: Dr. Charles Smith, visionary artist and creator of the African-American Heritage Museum and Black Veterans Archive, at his trailer-house studio in Hammond, La.
multimedia.copyright: Annie Flanagan for The New York Times

title: Bad Bunny’s ‘Un Verano Sin Ti’ Spends a Fourth Week at No. 1
abstract: Since its release, the Puerto Rican superstar’s album has earned the equivalent of 1.4 million sales and picked up 1.9 billion streams in the United States alone.

multimedia.caption: Over its nine weeks on sale, the numbers for Bad Bunny’s “Un Verano Sin Ti” have gradually declined, but still remained higher than almost anything else on the chart.
Over its nine weeks on sale, the numbers for Bad Bunny’s “Un Verano Sin Ti” have gradually declined, but still remained higher than almost anything else on the chart.

title: A Perfect Weekend in Asbury Park, N.J.
abstract: An hourlong drive from Manhattan offers a seaside idyll for rockers, diners, surfers, art patrons and fans of just relaxing on the beach. Here’s how to make the most of a weekend there.

multimedia.caption: Non-surfers eager to shred can book lessons at Asbury Park’s surf beach through Summertime Surf.
Non-surfers eager to shred can book lessons at Asbury Park’s surf beach through Summertime Surf.

title: Ada Limón Is Named the Next Poet Laureate
abstract: Poetry, she said, can help the nation “become whole again” in a fraught, divided moment.

multimedia.caption: Poetry, said Ada Limón, the 24th U.S. poet laureate, “helps us remember that we too are an imperfect animal, and we too are nature.”
multimedia.copyright: Carla Ciuffo for The New York Times

title: Nine People Under One Roof for Two Weeks? Have Fun!
abstract: In her new novel, “Any Other Family,” Eleanor Brown shows how nonstop togetherness can lead to tension, injury and, occasionally, joy.

abstract: Jimmy and Kim get a new refrigerator. Gus and Lalo get some quality face time.

title: ‘White on White’ Review: American Grotesque
abstract: Robert Quillen Camp’s play, about an antiracist discussion group, starts out naturalistically, but then pivots, with bloody abandon, to the absurd.

multimedia.caption: Heather E. Cunningham, left, and Nisi Sturgis in “White on White” at the Off Off Broadway space JACK in Brooklyn.
Heather E. Cunningham, left, and Nisi Sturgis in “White on White” at the Off Off Broadway space JACK in Brooklyn.

title: Among the Literary Lions, at Full Roar, in the 1980s
abstract: In “Circus of Dreams,” the literary editor John Walsh writes about the bookish life in London when Martin Amis, Ian McEwan, Jeanette Winterson and their generation were in the increasingly bright limelight.
des_facet: Circus of Dreams: Adventures in the 1980s Literary World (Book)

title: India and the United States: Two Countries That Can’t Live With Each Other or Without Each Other
abstract: Meenakshi Ahamed’s “A Matter of Trust” traces the tangled, complicated and difficult relationship between two allies that are not quite friends.
des_facet: A Matter of Trust: India-US Relations From Truman to Trump (Book)

multimedia.caption: An official reception for Donald and Melania Trump, New Delhi, February 2020.
An official reception for Donald and Melania Trump, New Delhi, February 2020.

title: Imagining an Exodus: ‘Ain’t No Mo’’ to Take Flight on Broadway
abstract: The play, by Jordan E. Cooper, is a biting comedy set in an America that offers to relocate Black citizens to Africa.

multimedia.caption: Jordan E. Cooper as Peaches, a check-in agent for a flight bound for Africa, in Cooper’s play "Ain't No Mo’."

title: A Glimpse Inside a Florentine Silk-Weaving Workshop
abstract: The Antico Setificio Fiorentino, which relies on looms from the 18th and 19th centuries, has been producing precious textiles since 1786.

title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Everything’s Trash’ and ‘The Rehearsal’
abstract: New shows from the idiosyncratic comedy creators Phoebe Robinson and Nathan Fielder debut on Freeform and HBO.

title: ‘Hollywood Ending,’ a Cradle-to-Jail Biography of Harvey Weinstein
abstract: Ken Auletta looks for Weinstein’s Rosebud in this dispiriting account of the former movie mogul’s life.
des_facet: Hollywood Ending: Harvey Weinstein and the Culture of Silence (Book)

title: Some Surprising Good News: Bookstores Are Booming and Becoming More Diverse
abstract: More than 300 bookstores have opened in the past couple of years — a revival that is meeting a demand for “real recommendations from real people.”
byline: By Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth A. Harris

title: When a Professor Trades the Academy for an Art Career of His Own
abstract: For Thomas Woodruff, retirement from teaching offered the very thing he’d been trying to instill in his students: artistic freedom.

multimedia.caption: At the top of the stairs into Woodruff’s studio in Germantown, N.Y., a pastel of a brontosaurus leans against a credenza — a homage to the Hollywood Cemetery, complete with a portrait of Elsa Lanchester in “The Bride of Frankenstein” (1935) — by the artist Shawn Peterson.

title: The New New Haven
abstract: Unexpectedly, the Connecticut city has emerged, both because of and despite its association with Yale, as an affordable and dynamic home for artists of all kinds.

multimedia.caption: Jason Price (left) and Titus Kaphar in front of a former ice cream factory that is now part of NXTHVN in New Haven, Conn. The architect Deborah Berke expanded two existing buildings into a state-of-the-art arts center that includes studios, event spaces and a gallery.

abstract: A familiar face in Woody Allen movies, he became widely known for his portrayal of Paulie Walnuts on the hit HBO series.

title: Susie Steiner, Author of Acclaimed British Crime Novels, Dies at 51
abstract: Her books found a worldwide audience, but while she wrote them she had to contend with the loss of her sight and the diagnosis of a brain tumor.

multimedia.caption: The author Susie Steiner, whose Manon Bradshaw detective novels became popular both in England and abroad, in an undated photo.

abstract: The former secretary of state moderated a discussion on Friday afternoon about successes and barriers for women working in the theater.

title: Remembering James Caan and His Potent Mix of Swagger and Delicacy
abstract: “The Godfather” helped open up a range of roles for the actor that allowed him to play against type and expectation in wonderful ways.
